One thing we need to do is move water from the ocean back inland to places we need it and if we can do that while generating clean energy we have a chance to mitigate climate change and still have a prosperous future. It is really, really hard but it is not impossible.

The biggest idea I am trying to express is tunneling aqueducts from the coast, in this case the west coast of the USA inland to feed combination geothermal power and sea water desalination plants. The idea seems to be so big that no one has considered it possible but I believe it is not only possible but it is necessary. For over a century the fossil water contained in aquifers has been pumped out to feed agriculture, industry and municipal water needs. The natural water cycle cant refill fossil water deposits that were filled 10,000 years ago when the glaciers melted after the last ice age. Without refilling these aquifers there is not much of a future for the region of the United states. As a result ground levels in some areas of the San Joaquin Valley have subsided by more than 30 feet. Similar fossil water depletion is happening in other regions all around the world. TBM and tunneling technology has matured and further developments in the industry are poised to speed up the tunneling process and it's these tunnels that are the only way to move large volumes of water from the ocean inland. The water is moved inland to areas where it can be desalinated in geothermal plants producing clean water and power. In many cases the water will recharge surface reservoirs where it will be used first to make more hydro power before being released into rivers and canal systems. It's very important however to not stop tunneling at these first stops but to continue several legs until the water has traveled from the ocean under mountain ranges to interior states. Along the way water will flow down grade through tunnels and rise in geothermal loops to fill mountain top pumped hydro batteries several times before eventually recharging several major aquifers. What I am proposing is essentially reversing the flow of the Colorado River Compact. Bringing water from the coast of California first to mountaintop reservoirs then to the deserts of Nevada and Arizona and on to Utah, New Mexico, Colorado and Wyoming. This big idea looks past any individual city or states problems and looks at the whole and by using first principles identifies the actual problem and only solution.

Thank you for your time, I would like the opportunity to explain in further detail and answer any questions.

Needs a correction at the end. Before the advent of agriculture - hunter-gatherers did not spend "all day every day just finding food". There is a lot that can be debated about how much leisure time such peoples had, including isolated hunter-gatherer groups still around today or in recent times. But, those quoted words are simply false. Hunter gatherers may have had more leisure time than agricultural societies. This is not hard to imagine in a lush landscape and a less human populated world, not restricting a groups migration. Just one mammoth, by the way, could feed a small group for a long time, and they learned to preserve the meat in water and probably other ways. There could also be ample food to be picked from flora. This should not just be labeled "spending all day looking for food". They knew where to look, and picking fruits and nuts from trees for your clan is not exactly back-breaking work. Using fertilizer like potash for modern agriculture isn’t liberating people. All organisms without predators, when given a surplus of resources will reproduce until their resources are exhausted and then experience mass die off. In humans, fertilizers cause growth beyond what the land could otherwise support. This makes us dependent on industrial production and global supply lines, while making us extremely vulnerable to any disruption or change of policy. Most of all, the surplus derived from fertilizer and industrial agriculture do not liberate people because it is not distributed equally. If productive capacity and efficiency made us wealthier, the work week would be shrinking. Instead the surplus becomes concentrated, creating a class who drive up prices of scarce things like homes and land. This condemns a subordinate class to a lifetime of rental housing, and buying prepared food, regressively funnelling value from the bottom to the top.

Sir Humphry Davies invented the Mine Safety Lamp that allowed the use of an open flame lamp inside coal mines that was prone to have methane on the ceiling.   Before that time, they used the Spedding Wheel that sprayed sparks off a piece of flint when a spinning wheel knocked off lots of tiny glowing particles.  This worked until a 12 year old boy showed off for the mine superintendent.  The resulting blast killed 117 miners.  The only survivor was the 12 year old boy that cranked the wheel fast and sprayed the hot sparks up to the ceiling.  Sir Humphry Davies then worked on the problem and found out that a flame will not pass through a gauze of wire mesh ( window screen ).  The gauze cooled the flame enough that the methane oxygen mix did not ignite.   Davies scared the hell out of miners when he first entered a mine with an open flame mine lamp ( with a gauze cover ).

Sometime in the late 50's we had a high school chemistry teacher that did that a similar but much less dramatic demonstration of potassium and one of the kids snuck a little piece of potassium and put it in his pants pocket.  Well before too long the oil had soaked into the cloth and the potassium starts getting uncomfortably hot.  Kid can't take it any more, runs into the bathroom, whips off his pants, which are smoking now, and throws them in the toilet.  A moment later you've got a dripping wet kid standing there without any pants, a shattered toilet bowl, water spraying everywhere, and everybody coming running to see what that loud noise was.  As I heard the story the kid didn't get any punishment except to help clean up the mess (once someone found some pants for him) as all the teachers figured he'd been punished enough and had learned his lesson.  That story was told to me in the late 70's by one of the teachers that had been there at the time, and he still couldn't get through it without laughing.  He wouldn't tell me who the kid was though.  It was somebody still in town he said, and no need to dig up old embarrassments.

"The use of ash obtained from plants as fertilizer has been known since ancient times. Poland has been an exporter of potash for quite some time. The peak of potash production in Poland was achieved in the 17th and 18th centuries. Polish specialists in the production of potash were so valued that, on the initiative of Captain John Smith, they were brought by English colonists to America. On October 1, 1608, a group of Polish craftsmen, specialists in the production of soap, potash and glass, arrived at the first settlement of English colonists in North America called Jamestown on the British ship "Mary and Margaret" and established the first manufacturing factories on the American continent. The craftsmen producing potash were therefore the ancestors of the present-day American Polish community. Ignacy Krasicki, the poet, expressed the importance of potash production for the economy of the Republic of Poland in one of his epigrams:

"If there were no potash
There would be no inventory;
The treasure is not worshiped enough
We have gallons from the ashes. " -
Ignacy Krasicki (1735 - 1801)"

Between 1420 and 1620, the primary exporting cities for wood-derived potash were Gdańsk, Königsberg and Riga. From the 1640s, geopolitical disruptions (i.e. Russo-Polish War (1654–1667)) meant that the centres of export moved from the Baltic to Archangel, Russia. In 1700, Russian ash was dominant though Gdańsk remained notable for the quality of its potash. In the late fifteenth century, London was the lead importer due to its position as the centre of soft soap making while the Dutch dominated as suppliers and consumers in the sixteenth century.

I believe we have to accept that we humans are not perfect beings and that we may not be able to grasp or perceive everything that is out there with our given senses and intellectual/mental powers. Perhaps what we can perceive, for example, corresponds to only about 10% of all that actually exists. Even the tools and instruments that we develop to better observe, measure and understand our environment (including the universe) are tools that are developed on the basis of our perception and mental/intellectual power. For example, the most complex instrument an ape is able to develop is a simple stick. His intellectual powers are insufficient to grasp/understand what lies beyond "stick".
So it may be that we will never understand certain things because we cannot perceive/grasp them. This is not contradicted by the fact that our instruments are constantly improving and we understand our environment better and better. And of course we should always continue to do research. But it can be, I actually think it is very likely, that there is a limit that is naturally drawn by our senses and mental/intellectual powers (see ape example). And the explanations for many things we do not understand may lie beyond that boundary and therefore remain hidden from us forever.

The Davy lamp is actually the second lamp that was designed to be used in areas where firedamp was a concern. The first lamp was created by George Stephenson, up here in the North East of England. In fact, the "Geordie Lamp" was in use for a couple of years before Davy demonstrated his own lamp. The reason the Davy lamp became common was purely down to discrimination - nobody believed that a poor, uneducated enginewright could possibly have created such a device. It wasn't until a committee of enquiry was held that Stephenson was exonerated, but by then the damage was done. Interestingly enough, the Geordie lamp was actually superior - with a high enough concentration of firedamp, the Geordie lamp would self-extinguish. This was in contrast to the Davy lamp, which would simply increase in temperature until it became unbearable to hold, and the lamp failed and the firedamp exploded anyway.

You are really good on the science, and I learned a lot in a very fun way. However, you repeat a common myth about earlier cultures we call "hunter gatherers," saying that they spent every waking hour seeking food and therefore were not free like us to do things like art. It took a Native American tribe here in California about two weeks to gather enough acorns to provide their staple food for an entire year. The hunters were a small class of folks in the typical tribe, so that labor was not done by most of the tribe. As for berries and other foods that supplemented the acorn flour staple, the people knew where these plants grew, and sometimes planted them in accessible places themselves, though in the natural landscape so they did not look like our agriculture. So gathering these was more akin to stepping into your yard and picking some tomatos for tonight's salad. Far from being "primitive." indigenous, tribal cultures knew how to grow and access plant foods in a way that was sustainable and so in harmony with the natural landscape that the "sophisticated and advanced" Europeans couldn't even recognize them. And, by the way, that is why museums all over the world do not have enough space to display all of the art they have gathered that was, and still is, created by the tribal peoples. The majoirity of the plant foods we have in our diet we learned about from those "hunter-gatherers." And they did it without thrashing the ecosystem. So who is the primitive?

Potatoes have become expensive. I buy one potato for $1; let the roots grow on them; cut them into several pieces; put them in a big container; add potassium to the soil, and after 20 days, I get 30 potatoes not as big as the original but substantial enough to make succulent Gratin Dauphinois for six people. In order to keep potatoes going, you can keep 20 containers producing successful potatoes in line-up succession. This is how the Irish were able to survive. It requires nearly no work and insects don't eat the green plant. You can cultivate the potatoes once the plant has become brown. By the way, from my own experience potatoes do much better in containers than in the soil.

40+ years ago at Texas A&M there was a professor who was experimenting with using copper chloride in solution pumped through twinwall thin polycarbonate sheets covering a greenhouse to attempt to extract the infra-red portion of sunlight and reduce the excessive heat load in greenhouses. I have laced polycaprolactone (PCL) polymer (i.e., polymorph or instamorph) with 1 to 2% copper salts to try to make it less biodegradeable, but a week ago when I molded structural pieces of this copper modified PCL and placed it on a boat in Texas heat, it absorbed so much infra-red from direct sunlight it all melted, even though it's melting point is listed at 160F.

I've actually seen this in person and wondered wtf they were as well. They're shaped very similarly to some other colorful artificial ponds in the desert here in Utah (albeit ones which are much further north, west of the Great Salt Lake), which are evaporation brine ponds used by the Moreton Salt Co. to harvest sodium chloride from the plentiful underground salt springs found throughout the Bonneville Salt Flats.

These brine ponds are always various shades of hot pink and neon magenta verging on purple sometimes, like I personally always thought of them as looking like someone liquefied flamingos lol. The vivid colors are due to (harmless) halophilic bacteria (or maybe they're actually archaea? I always forget) which thrive in the ultra-high salinity conditions where no other life can survive, and they use an array of bright pink and violet pigments to perform a type of photosynthesis without chlorophyll (at least if I'm remembering correctly, it's been a while since I've read up on this stuff, so feel free to correct me anyone).

The whole northern portion of the Great Salt is also pinkish-violet due to halophiles (it's functionally a separate lake from the southern portion nowadays due to the railroad causeway that was build cutting across the lake in the 1950s, which cut off the north part from the in-flow of the Jordan River, so there's more evaporation and the water has gained a way higher salt concentration than the south, leading to a different ecology with less brine shrimp and cyanobacteria and more halophiles). It's a pretty surreal and spectacular sight, albeit one that's arguably the result of reckless environmental tampering from humans.

While I find the information very interesting, I take issue with some of the claims about agriculture (I am a veterinarian who focuses on environmental and agricultural science and resource management). A lot of the expansion of agriculture is really not sustainable and we will not continue to be able to support the number of people currently alive using the methods we have now (it causes long term degradation and there are tons of resources lost to what are now known to be poor land management techniques). Current agriculture just borrows resources from the future to support people now, assuming that technology will be invented that will make up the losses from erosion, lack of topsoil, and overuse of fertilizers, pesticides, and herbicides. That’s not even mentioning most of the lost ecosystem services or beginning to address “animal agriculture.”

The video also does not address the health problems associated with potash and other forms of mining (including issues with the water table in the area), usually suffered by poorer communities and Native Americans (check out the continuing problems with abandoned uranium mines on Navajo land in New Mexico for an important Pin Drop story).

There is a huge amount of water waste that goes into recovering potash. The use of water from the Colorado River is so skewed that the water that once flowed all the way to Mexico is now a dry riverbed before it ever reaches the ocean. Climate change will cause the loss of about 5-20% more water from the Colorado, and a majority of the water is used to support agriculture that is not well-placed (given the tendency to drought recently). There are likely better ways to recover evaporated water, but they would require more investment and there is little incentive for companies to do so.

I should admit that ancient hunter-gatherers DIDN'T actually spend "all day every day" to find food. Modern hunter-gatherers societies which still exists in some isolated areas spend ~3-5 hours per day to sustain themselves (well, if they were lucky enought to be located in areas isolated enough to not be dislodged from fertile land).

Actually, invention of the ancient agriculture drastically decreases possibility - at least for the vast majority of population - to explore any "different way of life". Or to explore virtually anything, after all. Peasant communities tend to be quite conservative, you know - for a reason. You need all your time and energy just to sustain and survive - you have no resources for...silly experiments.

Yes, modern agriculture with all the machines, fertilizers and science is labor-effective way to get the food. But even the couple of centuries ago being peasant - i.e. for 95%+ of population - means hard monotonous work from sunset to dawn. Pre-modern agriculture is much, MUCH more labor-intensive way to get food if compared to hunting-gathering.

Reality is grim: key advantage of agriculture - pre-modern one, even ancient one - is that piece of land may support much bigger population if cultivated. Somewhat about tenfolds more peasants that hunters on the same area. Peasants has worse, grim, unpleasant and often shorter life filled with hard monotonous work and almost always with much more infant mortality rate. But there are just _a lot of them_, and it's a key...well...military/evolutionary advantage. This unhappy peasants just crowded out hunters-gatherers, despite their generally higher quality of life.

That's why we have impression that hunting-gathering is more labor-intensive than it is - hunter-gatherers were dislodged from fertile land to the desolated, harsh places. American native bison hunters definetely NOT spend all their time to sustain themselves. But native americans in reservations? They do.

And probaly that's why hunting was almost universally quite strictly forbidden - for peasants - in most of the medieval societies.

At least it's how I understand contemporary scientific consensus on the matter.
I may collect some, well, reliable peer reviewed sources on the matter, if necessary.

Please do a follow on to the potash video. Check this out. Potash is used to make soap, which pioneers and farmers used for a couple of centuries. But Native American's also used potash. Likely they discovered this by accident. The would boil corn in clay pot over a fire. But ashes falling into the water made the corn softer and easier to eat, so I suspect later this was done intentionally. [This comes from The Cooking School website] Hominy comes from yellow or white maize, also known as field corn. Dried hominy kernels are soaked in an alkali solution of lye or slaked lime. This process, called nixtamalization, removes the hull and germ, making the corn easier to grind and cook with. Nixtamalization also helps the kernels release more of their nutrients, including niacin (also known as vitamin B3), and makes them easier to digest, too.

To stave off starvation during the Irish potato famine, corn was imported from the United States. But the corn sent was "field corn" used as animal feed. This might have been a great help, but the Irish did not have the knowledge of how to prepare the corn to make it edible.

Side note: The Irish potato famine resulted from a period of wet weather, which created ideal conditions for the plant fungal disease called phytopthora infastans, which devastated the potato crop. This weather was experienced all over Europe, but the famine was limited to Ireland, because farmers in these other regions had access to many other food sources.

See "Myths of the Irish Potato Famine" An observer of the time, in 1846, wrote the following in a letter to the Primer Minister:

For 46 years the people of Ireland have been feeding those of England with the choicest produce of their agriculture and pasture; and while they thus exported their wheat and their beef in profusion, their own food became gradually deteriorated…until the mass of the peasantry was exclusively thrown on the potato.. . . It was impoverishment under British rule that caused so many Irish to be dependent on potatoes, not a silly decision to plant nothing but potatoes. A poor Irish family might have had as little as one-quarter acre of land on which to grow crops for export, raise a pig, and grow enough potatoes to keep from starving.

Love this content but I have one mild criticism.  Many videographers use the call of the cactus wren when showing desert scenes.  The sound has become an icon denoting wild desert landscapes. But cactus wrens don’t live near Moab or those evaporation ponds where the video was made.  they live in the Sonoran Desert much farther south, usually associated with stands of cholla (teddy bear cactus) and saguaro.  It is a wonderful sound like the bark of the coyote or the call of the loon.  It is the audible embodiment of saguaro country.  A canyon wren (not cactus wren) or raven would be a better choice for sound effects in the Moab area.  Your video still gets an A+ in my opinion.

The german ban/restrictions of potash exports in 1910 wasn´t a preemptive first strike in view of a/the war. From my quick research, it had to do with syndicates in the german potash industry, US involvment in it, lower prices for american companies, as a result the felt need of germany to protect its national resources and the fear of "strengthening foreign nations at the expense of the Fatherland". The german potash law of 1910 therefore was more about economics and nationalism than a future war.
As a german and a historian I never heard of it before and was pleasantly suprised that my research turned out to be that interesting. It seems the history of potash is quite the curious subject. :D

It's a myth that hunter gatherers spent so much time getting food. The reason why farming promoted advanced civilization was because it promoted bigger settlements - cities. As food could be stored in a more concentrated manner. Farming allows for big armies to exist.. Also farming does require more planning and understanding of seasons. Storing grain and selling it requires some math skills and weight measurement. The list is long.
On the other hand hunter gatherers by definition had to live in small dispersed groups. Suffice it to say it's not about time spent so much. It's other factors.

People in the past did not spend all day every day searching for food. In many cases, they had it easier than modern people. One buffalo, for example, would have fed quite a number of people for many days. Corn was stored in underground sand pits dug by the American Natives, and growing corn was not really all that difficult.
There were many more fish, shellfish, small game animals and birds around, and even the water supply provided in rivers and creeks would have been readily available and clean along with crayfish and turtles, all eaten by people for centuries.
Many of the early races inhabiting the North American continent had more than enough food stored to last the entire winter when hunting and fishing were difficult or impossible, so you can safely bet that there was a not a lot of tramping around all day for food with five feet of snow around your tepee.

Homemade, "country" soap was made by percolating water slowly through wood ashes, in what was called an "ash hopper". This contraption was constructed so as to create a slow but steady dribble of concentrate out the bottom, into a catch-pan. This was then mixed with lard to make soap: lye soap.
What some, today, say as "my nose is running like a grass hopper" is nonsense: the phrase is, in fact, "my nose is running like an ash hopper."

Hunter gatherers lifestyles actually required less labor than agricultural lifestyles. In fact, in the beginning, agriculture was objectively worse than nomadism and the hunter-gatherer lifestyle. Agricultural societies: worked more, had unhealthy diets that were very unvaried (possibly relying on most of their calories from one crop), they were more susceptible to disease, they had to deal with famines, and they lived shorter lives. The narrative of progress and civilization is not entirely accurate. Of course eventually benefits came from agriculture, but it took literal millenniums until then.

18:04 - 18:30 I must point out that that is a myth. Hunter-gatherers, today and thousands of years ago, had much more free time than agrarian people. It is believed that they only had around a 30 hour work week, leaving the rest of the time for thinking, storytelling, leisure, and learning. The grind of farming took way more work and way more time. It was only developed in places where the population was so high, it was necessary to support everyone. However yes, after industrialization, innovations and inventions such as mining potash, did allow for agriculture to become much more efficient the majority of the population to work other jobs (mostly scheduled this time though).

Copper sulfate is used in pesticides and is used as a fungicide and also in swimming pools for the same reason- hence the blue color. You don't want to absorb a lot of copper into your body because it can have very negative effects, you only need a tiny bit of copper. This is also why when people take antibiotics copper that is in their tissues is released and fights against fungi and diseases. Too much copper can result in something called copper overload. Trust me it's nasty I've had it. Zinc, chromium picolinate and molybdenum are all copper antagonists and can keep them in check.

18:09 Hunter Gatherers did not spend all day every day searching for food- Marshall Sahlins argued in 1966 that they only spent 3-5 hours a day doing that. They probably had much more leisure time than modern workers. "Sahlins argues that hunter-gatherer tribes are able to meet their needs through working roughly 15-20 hours per week or less." When challenged that he didn't include time spent processing and preparing food (and activities like gathering firewood; which is unrelated to the point you're making about fertilizer in this video), Sahlins' estimate was revised up to ~44hrs/week for men and ~40hrs/week for women on all types of work, including housework and food prep. Modern workers spend AT LEAST 8hrs/day and 40hrs/week on their jobs alone; if you include housework tasks like cooking, cleaning, shopping, and errands, that expands to consume a vast portion of modern lives- much more than 8hrs/day or 40hrs/week.

While you still have a point that abundant agriculture can reduce time spent producing food from 3-5 to 0 hours per day, because a modern worker instead acquires food by earning money at a differentiated task, you make a very misleading statement in the process of making that point which could give viewers a very misguided view of a different scientific topic.

7. It relates to George Washington merely because he is the person that signed the patent for a more efficient way to gather potash.

9. It relates to every other people because potassium are fertilizer for agriculture.

Potassium inherited the bad sides of its good ones. In agriculture, the amount of utilized potassium grew so rapidly that it has now become a huge problem. Because most lands where it's spread upon (as a fertilizer for plants), are not the lands where it originaly formed. Making those first ones over-rich in potassium salts (hydroxyde, carbonate, sulfate, etc. depending on conditions).
This is due to one of its bad sides : nearly every soil types are unable to capture and keep potassium... it gets washed by infiltrating water from the rain (or irrigation), and goes deeper and deeper out of reach from roots.
That has turned some soils into depending so much on fertilizing that they are now considered "human dependant". In large areas of the USA, but for most of those into "industrial agriculture" as well, soil is so destructured by massive use of fertilizers (mainly potassium, phosphate, nitrogen) or salt-rich feces rejected by cattle that it has became some sort of dust. You take it into your hand and, no matter the rate of hygrometry, it flows in-between your fingers like powder.

Very interesting story about potassium. However research tends to contradict your conclusion (you can find those research references in the book Homo Sapient a Brief History of Mankind)
Hunter gatherer were probably spending less time sourcing their food than the peasant of the pre industrial era. It is estimated at about 4 hours a day, which free a lot of time for other social activity. They were less subject to starvation as they were relying on multiple source of food and had a more nutritious diet.
In the chapter of the book "the domestication of humans by cereals" (such a good title!) the author try to present how unfavourable this lifestyle trade of (nomad hunter gatherer to sedentarian harvester) and it is only couple of hundred years that this strategy paid off. And even now, the average human will work 8/10 hours a day and have significantly less leisure time as our hunter gatherer ancestors. They were also enjoying art, music and science and in a more equal society.
I would also mention the risk of the fertiliser dependency of our modern agriculture as we are relying on the mining of a finite resources (this is especiallytrue for Nitrogen). Some researchers are predicting a shortage of potassium around 2040. The destruction of the natural cycle of Nitrogen creation has been broken by human activities and the actual population growth can only be sustained with the use of fertilisers and intensive agriculture..

You're wrong about why the reaction of Potassium metal with water exploded.  Yeah, the hydrogen burns, but it doesn't explode.  What you witnessed was a coulomb explosion.  When the Potassium reacts with the water it forms a positive charge.  And what happens when two positive charge come close to each other?  They repel each other.  Now, times that by billions of atoms that all repel each other at once and you get an explosion.  A coulomb explosion.  This is why all alkali metals below lithium explode on contact with water.  You can't get hydrogen to burn without oxygen, and you can get alkali metals to explode in an oxygen-less atmosphere.  Thunderfoot has a great video on this, as do I.  You can go to my channel and watch my sodium and potassium videos and see that they exode under water with no bubbles of hydrogen to burn.  You can also fill a balloon with hydrogen and set it on fire and it won't explode like in your video.  This is a very common misconception.   So I can't blame you for getting it wrong.  It's only been discovered in the last few years that alkali metals explode in water due to coulombs law and a coulomb explosion.  You should do a follow up video on this and explain the real reason why they explode on contact with water.  It would be an extremely interesting video, man.

As someone who grew up in moab, this is pretty interesting. Parts of this I've never heard before. Did somewhat fascinating that the two biggest mineral extraction industries that put Moab on the map, we're both caused by Germany. The first being as described in the video the demand for potassium around world war I. The second mineral boom was the search for uranium following the development of the atomic industry during and following world war II. People think of Moab for some of the best of four wheeling anywhere to be found as well as some of the best bicycling, but they don't think about how years before any of this happened uranium and potash developed and sustained a pretty awesome community. And this doesn't even mention the national parks and monuments on each side of town plus the state parks and lands in the area. Arches national Park in canyonlands national Park are a couple of the most photographed places in the world.

Water is polar and almost instantly sucks electrons from alkali metal atoms that are more than happy to give them up. This leaves positively charged ions close together. That chemical fertilizers are the ones that made agriculture more productive is a misconception. Fertilizers were known way before chemistry as a science was established and any kind of chemical product was mass produced. What made agriculture more productive is engines. A tractor can plow as much as ten horses in less than half the time. A harvester can do in one day what many people and animals did in a month. But cow dung or guano are even better for increasing crop production than chemical fertilizers. In fact, chemical fertilizers require more work than natural ones - you need to carefully mix and match different fertilizers, and chop and add organic matter, to prevent soil erosion or compaction (which few farmers do anyway, and then they wonder why their land degrades), in order to get the same effect as properly aged manure achieves with no mixing effort whatsoever.

Great video, very interesting! But I have to raise one question about something you said at the end: I recently read a book (I think it was Sapiens), in which the author (among many other things) describes our transition from hunter-gatherers to farmers to industrialized individuals. It said that the amount of hours spent "sustaining ourselves", eg. gathering, farming or today working was the lowest during the hunter-gathering phase, where we supposedly only spent a couple to a handful of hours each day, leaving the most time for creative activities, socializing etc. Then farming came along and "won out" because it was so much more scalable and reliable, but on average increased the daily workload of humans massively. Today, most industrialized nations where people work 40 hour a week land somewhere in between. You mentioned that hunter-gatherers spent "all day every day" searching for food, and I wonder if any research was made to back up that statement or if it slipped through as something that "seems plausible". Either way it doesn't undermine the main content of the video, just a detail that got me thinking.

Fascinating stuff but Derek Muller makes a misstep when he reiterates a commonly cited but untenable notion about a sharp contrast between agricultural and hunter gatherer societies, with the latter dominated by the need to secure the physical conditions of life with little lesuire time and the former that as a result of radically transforming the relationship of dependence on the environment offers bountiful lesuire time and the opportunity to fully develop the arts and sciences. Those are issues that go beyond the story of potash, of course, but addressing them directly is called for because Derek's old school history about the development of the arts and sciences is mystifying. Agricultural societies do not free up people's time to follow artistic or scientific pursuits. On the contrary, more people toil than ever to produce food to sustain life and more of people's time than ever must be devoted to achieving a viable subsistence (in early agricultural societies) or to gain a wage/income (in our world) that is sufficient for a life without deprivation. Hunter-gatherer societies qualify as the original affluent society (Marshall Sahlins) in which all the people's wants were fairly easily satisfied.

There is also a misjudgement about how art and science figure in societies at large. 'Free time' isn't the driving force behind the development of art and science even if curiosity (and the boundlessness of curiosity) is indeed very much at play. But, the paths followed by a curious mind are always conditioned by the prevailing needs within particular forms of life. Fortunately for us, a curious mind will also be very attuned to features of our world and our form of life that act as ostacles to the satisfaction of our needs. So, being a needful creature motivates our artistic and scientific explorations and ignites our critical sensibilities, too.

While it's great that we have been able to advance society and feed more people, there should be some questions raised about how long we can continue industrial farming where each field is mono-cultured, sprayed with pesticides, compressed by large harvesting machines that kill whatever soil life remains after all that mono-culture, then having to dump tons of fertilizer all over it to make anything be able to grow there, and then repeat that process year after year, decade after decade, killing our soil. And then to realize that to make all that fertilizer, we are also adding copper sulfate on massive levels to an environment...
It's a bit insane, when converting to more natural farming methods could almost eliminate the need for (artificial) fertilizer all together in many parts of the world. But we have come to rely on a profit-generating, food-wasting system where all food is available everywhere at unrealistic prices all the time and supermarket shelves always HAVE to be full to sell more and all produce has to look like it does on the advertisement, meaning diversity and nutritiousness takes a back seat to marketability. We need to turn this oil-tanker around at some point, though, or risk a dust-bowl-like disaster on a global scale... oh and with an increased chance of zoonosis viruses like Covid because of biodiversity decline.

Tonight, We make soap. To make soap, first we render fat.
The salt content has to be just right, so the best fat comes from humans.
<This is why we raid the biohazard dumpsters at liposuction clinics. The richest, creamiest fat is found there... The fat of the land!>
As the fat renders, the tallows float to the surface, like in Boy Scouts.
Once the tallows harden, you can skim off a layer of glycerin.
If you were to add nitric acid, you get nitroglycerin.
If you were to then add ammonium nitrate and a dash of sawdust, you got dynamite.
Yeah, with enough soap, you could blow up just about anything!
Now, ancient people found that their clothes got clean when they washed them in a certain point in a river <Why?>
Because human sacrifices were once made above the river ... bodies burned, water seeped through the wood and ashes to create lye.
This is lye, the crucial ingredient. Once it mixed with the melted fat of the bodies a thick white soapy discharge crept into the river'.

It's not true to say that hunter-gatherers spent "all day, every day" finding food. They have more leisure time than farmers do, and a recent "primitive affluence"anthropological study from 2019 shows that at least one group of modern hunter-gatherers in the Philippines, the Agta, who are transitioning to an agricultural lifestyle are working longer hours because of it (especially women).

What agriculture does allow is the production of more food per hectare (and storable food, crucially) in many places, which means that a given piece of land can support a substantially higher population, which allows that population to militarily dominate those in surrounding areas – and get them to also start farming, thus producing storable food surpluses that the dominant population can extract. From there, we get empires and cities and an artisan class. But even though the adoption of agriculture enabled the existence of a lot more people, it wasn't necessarily an improvement in lifestyle on an individual level for most people.

It might be an interesting future video idea to get into the economic and nutritional aspects of hunter-gather societies versus agricultural societies both historic and prehistoric, and what anthropologists have been able to glean so far about why agriculture spread far and wide.

This is an incredible production and I have learned a great deal, but there is one thing I wish to add to better help people come away with a factual experience: Modern agriculture has not truly freed up people's time, it has made our freedoms shrink and has made our work lives longer. Hunter-Gatherers despite popular narratives only needed to spend roughly 16-24 hours per week foraging for food (depending upon geographic location, resource availability, etc). Humans with the advent of agriculture continually destroyed the edible biodiversity on earth, eradicating hundreds of botanicals and vegetables which thousands of years ago would have provided swifter access to a diverse food repertoire, further offering varied vitamins and nutrients. Notice now how people are abandoning monoculture farming (ie: the classic American corn breadbasket), and trying to go back to polyculture farming and harvesting. Perhaps there are applications in using potassium fertilizer in these polyculture-style farming regions, but we already know they are unnecessary, as polyculture farming on its own helps to mitigate pests and offers greater sustainable productivity. As usual, humanity shot itself in the foot and needed to get creative to solve a problem that should have never come to pass.

When I was about 15 I went to a summer science adademy (yes I was a smart little nerd), and the teacher who was teaching the academy was the stereotypical science geek with the horn rimmed glasses and a rather insanely curious gleam in his eye. One day we all donned our goggles, and he proceeded to take a very tiny piece of potassium and drop it in a 4 oz GLASS BEAKER with about 3 oz of water in it; It fizzled on top for a few seconds and then exploded-- sending shards of glass flying in all directions. Luckily we all had goggles and tough rubber lab aprons on. If I remeber right there were no serious injuries, but there were a few people with glass on their clothing, and a few had tiny pieces of glass embedded in their skin which had to be picked out with tweezers. It was a small town, and it was the early 90's so lawsuits and emotional trauma weren't really as much of a thing then. We just sortof all laughed about it, and went on to the next thing.

Gatherer-hunter societies spend on average 4 hours per day finding food, which is light work. Primitive agricultural societies have an average work day of 8-10 hours of hard labor.

Agriculture can support more people per acre land, but costs more labor per person to do so. It is not magic.

Fertilizer supports modern global agriculture, true, but is not needed to feed 7 billion humans. At present, 36% of all food grown is used as animal fodder, and there is additionally a huge amount of waste in the retail logistics of the so-called developed world.

When he says at 18:12 that "When our ancestors lived as hunter gatherers we spent all day every day just finding food", I believe he is sorely mistaken. It is my understanding that hunter gatherers only seek food for about 4 hours per day. Agriculture indeed supports more people than hunter/gathering does, but with a poorer diet we have not yet been able to evolutionarily adjust to. One theory suggests that agriculture developed not as a way to feed more people, but as a way to allow some people to accumulate wealth and power by taking a portion of what the others produce. Accumulation of wealth and power are exceedingly difficult in a subsistence lifestyle of the hunter gatherer. This would be a great Veritasium topic!

I smell the Law of Unintended Consequences lurking somewhere in the background.  Snowfall in the Rocky Mountains ultimately becomes ground water which coalesces into the Colorado River.  Downstream we pump it back into deep porous rock containing potassium salts, making a potassium brine aquifer which we pump to the surface, emptying that space, and depriving the natural groundwater of potassium downstream.  What could possibly go wrong?  BTW, I have no idea what the answer could be, or even if it's a valid question;  I'm just posing the question because our greatest failing as a species is our consistent refusal to ask WCPGW before it does.

Methane gas is present in all coal mines as well as potash and most other sedimentary deposited minerals such as the salt mines in Louisiana, for example. Mining engineers know how to mitigate and manage the presence of methane. Therefore, the decision to not mine this deposit using conventional processes was not driven by the presence of methane.

When the deposit was being developed, it was discovered that it was not a planar (flat) deposit as are those in Saskatchewan or Carlsbad, New Mexico. The deposit is folded and wrinkled like an unmade bed which made mining by traditional mechanical means uneconomic. So, a series of wells were drilled and water pumped down to dissolve the Potassium Chloride (KCl). Other wells driled to bring the solution to surface and allowed to evaporate, concentrate and then the KCl is harvested from the ponds and turned to the final products.

When I did my MSc. in Materials Engineering my thesis was about another piece of the fertilizer puzzle: Reactive Nitrogen. Without explaining a lot about my work (made under very destitute circumstances here in Venezuela) and only centering on the theoretic framework, it is to note that people had gone to war for Saltpeter. The Pacific War of 1879 to 1884 between Bolivia and Peru on one side, and Chile at the other (Chile won and took a piece of the Atacama desert that used to be Bolivia's access to the Pacific Ocean, effectively landlocking it) was fought for Saltpeter and... Guano. Sometimes they are referred as the "Guano Wars" XD.
So at one point before the Haber-Bosch process people literally fought for sh*t.
Personally if I were to found a school I would make mandatory an early curriculum on math and several courses on Industrial Processes and History of Science later. Ethics and Politics are also important!!! (in the Greek sense of both fields) =D .
Have a nice day!!! =D

My hypothesis is that the algorithm, rather than viewer preference, drives views on the site. As the algorithm shifts, various YouTubers experience burnout (as what used to work no longer works) and right now click-through rate is the key metric. So clickable titles and thumbnails are the only way to get a lot of impressions and hence views - they are the only way to go viral. This leads me to wonder which audiences will become most prevalent on the site and if there will even be a place for educational content. In the long-term, hopefully YouTube is able to measure satisfaction through surveys and other metrics to ensure an optimal experience for everyone on the site.

This has a crucial error- Americans did NOT cut down and burn forests in order to get potash- What they did was move westward, especially after the Revolution in order to open up new lands for settlement and for farming. In the first stage, they needed to clear forests to create farm fields. The first step was to burn those  trees not needed for fences and lumber to create potash to help pay for the first year on the land so that the settlers had enough to live on before the first crop could be harvested. The potash was sent long distances before payment could be returned. Sometimes it was used for barter. But the purpose was farming not potash. So many people took advantage of it that few did it for a living.

Please consider producing an episode about sustainable agricultural practices that focus on soil health and microbial life. Artificially adding potassium as a ‘fertilizer’ is not a long term solution to food production. Thanks!

One thing that astounded me about this video is...is there really that much potassium in hard wood? So I googled it and found that hardwood is 7-8% potassium. This is way higher than I would have guessed. I remember when Derek made a video about where the mass of a tree comes from. Most people guessed that it came from the ground, yet the truth is that most of it comes from the carbon dioxide in the air. Yet the potassium doesn't come from the air. Indeed, not a trifling amount does in fact come from the ground. This is one good reason not to cut down the rainforest and drag the trees away with the minerals.

In the old days in Denmark we used pine fungus (fire fungus) as a fire starter.
Grab the fungus from the tree.
Dry it for 3 weeks.
Chop it up.
Mix it with ash (potash) from a campfire.
Mix it with water and cook it for some hours.
Dry it up.
Now you got a good fire starter.

Were hunter gatherers truly spending most of their days looking for food?
Contrary to this seemingly popular notion, agriculture is actually the one that requires you to spend most of your day working. Agriculture is a very labor intensive field. What it does however is that it links production of food not just to labor but also something immovable and measurable - land. So whereas in a hunter gatherers society production was entirely tied to your labor and therefore your role in food production, an agricultural society created a class of people who didn't have to have a role in food production and make others do it for them. Agriculture is almost always more labor intensive. It just also produces a LOT more food. Think of an investment fund product that requires you to input a minimum of 100 dollars but will absolutely return 120. It's gonna outpace the growth of an equally 20%p smaller investment fund even if both funds are equally self sufficient.
Hunter gathers spent around three days finding food a week. You can't specialise without agriculture but it didn't save us time.

There is some misinformation here. One study of a contemporary hunter-gatherer culture concluded that the people were only spending 17% of their time on procuring food. How much time is required to procure food depends on geography (i.e. local abundance).

People were forced into agriculture when the local resources for hunter-gatherers became too scarce to feed everyone. From the earliest farmers right up to the present day, farmers have had to labor dawn to dusk to make a living from farming. Ultimately technology in the form of irrigation, tractors, artificial fertilizers, and pesticides has allowed a vast increase in productivity from a farmer's hard days work.

When the U.S. was founded 90% of the population worked as farmers. Today only around 3% of the U.S. population works in agriculture for a living.

Your explanation of the explosion from potassium is wrong. Look at the footage.

It doesn't happen at the surface; it happens under the water, where there is no oxygen. An explosion at the surface would consume the oxygen there, create water vapor, and push the rest of the oxygen from the atmosphere away, so the result would be about the same as potassium at the surface.

To be hydrogen-oxygen driven, you'd have to somehow argue that the hydrogen sucked the oxygen from the atmosphere in, and that's just not what you're seeing here (never mind that the oxygen would have to displace the water to climb down and mix with those hydrogen bubbles).

What you see instead is an explosion that displaces the water upwards from the bottom, and the vacuum left by the water sucks the bucket up. You can see the table wobbling and waving, as though it was a trampoline that was just jumped on. There is no way you can get a table to do that by putting an explosion above the water, as the explosion will displace some of the water, but the explosion will otherwise dissipate into the room. You would have to set off an explosion that would fry off your face if it blew at the top of the water to get this result.

No, what you're looking at is a coulomb explotion. Thunderf00t released a paper proving that the alkaline metals can happily generate explosions in an atmosphere without oxygen, which is only possible because what you're looking at is a coulomb explosion.

At least two MAJOR mistakes here.

—-

Firstly, it was in 1807 - not 1870 - when potassium was first discovered by Davy.

But it does so only at several hundred degrees (Celsius). With the exact melting point depending on which potassium salt, or mixture thereof, you use.

—-

It is for a reason that it took until 1807 to discover potassium.

Fun fact, the symbol of potassium is K because germans, who were leading the chemistry those days, refused to use vulgar English to sacred element names. So, they named it Kalium, which is a latin word(the origin of Kalium, “al-kali”, is actually from Arab) so all Germanic languages call it Kalium while all Romance languages call it potassium. Same principle, Na, which is sodium, calls Natrium.

This is certainly an impressive body of holistic educational information presented in under 20 minutes.  I say holistic because it’s not fractionated into discrete subjects like “chemistry” or “history” as the grossly outdated scholastic methods of the past.  But, I agree with the other commenters concerned about the “corporate” feel seeping in to this channel.  It’s becoming clear that the creative content creators that made YouTube great are now being targeted and “controlled” by corporate interests or “cloned” and counterfeited by corporate knockoffs.  For example, I saw one corporate YouTube channel about hunting for gold nuggets that featured young Asian females in bikinis standing knee deep in a creek with stainless steel fine meshed kitchen strainers allegedly finding large golf ball sized gold nuggets with ease.  The location was reported as an undisclosed island in a war torn third world country.  It was clear to me that these nuggets were just rocks spray painted with gold colored paint.  The underlying corporate messaging was clear.  “Gold is expensive because it’s found only in remote areas of the world plagued by war.  But, you can come to YouTube and watch young girls in bikinis find it with ease in a creek as corporate created content.  The channel had over 70,000 subscribers! The county only allowed a potash factory to be installed there because the local economy was based on uranium mining and milling, an industry which had just collapsed when the US gov't suddenly stopped purchasing uranium. So the locals were desperate to keep destroying their own landscape for money. This is what you get. Guess what? If this mine/factory didn't exist, it wouldn't affect the price of potash in the world at all, there wouldn't be any shortages, and in fact this factory produces potash at such an uneconomical rate, it's far cheaper to obtain from other places and other mines. Nowadays This factory makes and sells salt. Which, yeah, also not worth the impact. Since there's a whole lake full of salt a hundred miles away with no evaporation ponds necessary, or rather it's a big natural evaporation pond. Also potash is not really as important to industrial agriculture as nitrogen, that' pretty overstated that these evaporation ponds serve any useful or functional purpose beyond making money for the people who own them. Hey your wrong about hunter gathers spend ALL day gathering. Based off the few remaining hunter gathering tribes we know that hunter gathers had lots of leisure time. In fact they typically have more leisure time than current work force. It is early agriculture that was massive labor intensive. It's not free time, but surplus and specialization that lead to technological advancement. In a typically hunter gather tribe everyone must generally learn the same skills. Once you have one person producing a particular food and bartering with crafts people is when you have a real innovation. The potter, scribe, smith, or sheperd doesn't learn to grow grain because the farm does it well enough for them all.

I've always really enjoyed your videos, but I'm not sure this was made for people like me - it felt overproduced and the ending left me sad, because this advancement hasn't left most people I know with free time to explore their dreams, rather they're left without the means to produce or gather their own food and trapped in jobs they hate, scraping by just enough to keep a roof over their heads. Science has produced a huge number of ways for a few to profit, but many of those benefits do not reach those who really need them.

I really wish we lived in the utopia a lot of science communicators present, but sadly Covid has only re-confirmed for many of us that the distribution of necessities is highly imperfect and no amount of science advancement for "billions" in profit, changes that. Last week we got a call from a holocaust survivor in our community, who has a broken wrist and had no food in the house and we used our connections within food saving groups to help her out - no amount of science tech gives her freedom, as even before Covid her options for food were limited by inequality of financial means, social mobility and a lack of free elder care that means support relies on volunteers or being able to afford to pay for a carer. Distribution and assistance via volunteers is tough, too - we maintain our own vehicles to do so, most of which are from two plus decades ago and do not benefit from the advancements in modern, expensive vehicles.

I'm sorry, this is a rant that's gone rather off topic, but the overly optimistic and unbalanced nature of the close really got to me and I had to vent, regardless whether this comment will ever be read... I just really wish science was there to help us all equally and didn't have a preference for profiteering.

The explosion of potassium in water is often taught as the result of the hydrogen production.  This is not the case.  Instead, it is caused by rapid polarization at the atomic level creating a Coulomb force that exceeds the force binding the molecules together.  It is very similar to what happens when an overloaded capacitor explodes.

"[B]efore the advent of agriculture, when our ancestors lived as hunter-gatherers, we spent all day every day just finding food."

This is a myth, and I'm surprised to hear Veritasium repeat it. Anthropological studies of ancient and contemporary hunter-gatherer societies show that, on average, those societies actually have more leisure time than modern ones. In fact, as societies become more complex, the available amount of leisure time decreases (refer to Carol R. Ember's research on hunter-gatherers).

However, Veritasium is correct that the advent of agriculture allowed societies to grow more complex and encourage specialization of labor, which enabled widespread technological advancement.

When the world figures out that this system of producing food is unsustainable, they will realize that they should have been looking in other directions to support the food chain.  Animal manure has better characteristics and is better able to support plant growth that chemical fertilizers.  It also does not disrupt the natural biodiversity of the soil because it does not kill the beneficial microbes.  All in all it is far better than what we are using now.  Not only that, produce grown with animal manure as fertilizer has a much higher mineral content, making it more nutritious that foods grown with chemical fertilizer.

Ok. Dr. Derek Muller, I have a question for you, which you might want to pursue and help give us answers to. I have studied agriculture and understand the importance of Potassium; it's one of the 3 major macro-nutrients included in virtually every type of fertilizer. Access to isolated nutrients changed the game completely... and now I know how Potassium was discovered and isolated to begin with (thank you). But every type of fertilizer refers to it's "NPK values" – the ratio percentage of Nitrogen (N), Phosphorpus (P) and Potassium (K) within the fertilizer itself. These 3 nutrients benefit different aspects of a plant's growth (and the balance between them is vital). So, now my questions is "How about Nitrogen and Phosphorous? How were they discovered and isolated?" Can you explore this and the historical impact these discoveries had? As an agriculture specialist I think it's funny to think they started spreading tonnes of Potassium across fields, completely oblivious about the other two macro-nutrients and virtually throwing the soils nutrient content way off balance. I mean, it's the very balance between the three which is so key to producing good results to begin with. So what about Nitrogen and Phosphorous?

17:12 - What's up with this "al-ji" pronunciation? It's spelled "algae" (singular "alga"), and a G before an A is always hard (like the g in "toga", "mega", etc.).

Also, "ae" was never pronounced "i" or "ee". Originally (Greek / early Latin) it was pronounced "ae" or "eye", later it changed to "eh", like the E in "get" (to the point that a lot of words that used to be spelled with "ae" changed to "e" in late Latin and its derivatives).

I can sort of understand pronouncing "fungi" as "fun-ji" or "fun-guy" (both etymologically incorrect, but I guess it's easy to be misled by the modern spelling), but "algae" (alg-eye) never sounded like "al-ji" and doesn't even look like "al-ji".

I see some people saying you have got your derivation of the term 'pot' in potash wrong. To those people I say this: the Latin word 'pota' is a Latin adjective meaning drunken, deriving from the Latin verb 'poto', to drink (alcohol). Therefore, the 'pot' in potash does in fact come from the word pot, as pots were originally created to be a vassal used for storing alcohol in ancient Mesopotamia, hence the obvious ties. Make sure you are correct before you go bashing other people's work!

What he says about the stone age is not entirely true. He makes an argument of time: back before agriculture we supposedly spent all the time getting food. This is actually untrue: agriculture is wayyy more labor intensive than the nomadic lifestyle hunter gatherers enjoyed. In fact, it is estimated hunter-gatherers only spent about 4-5 hours a day looking for food. The reason why agriculture increased innovativeness is not about time, it's about numbers. Agriculture increased the carry capacity of the land, freeing up some few to specialize into other roles while the rest worked all day at farming.

Watched till 1:42,
so before watching the rest, here is my guess:
Were does the water come from? I think it's likely that it's pumped up from the ground. Those pools are clearly evaporation ponds, exposing as much surface to the sun as possible with the goal of letting the water evaporate. So there's probably something in the water that is being extracted here. My first guess would be Lithium, but I've never heard of a Lithium mine in Utah, or anywhere in the USA. So what else could it be? I'm going out on a Limb here, as I now very little about Chemistry, but let's have a look at the elements close to Lithium in the periodic table. Especially those in the same row. Natrium and Potassium come to mind. Natrium Chloride is Salt and mined in basically the same way that we see here. But that's also nothing special and happens all over the world. I have no idea if Potassium can be mined the same way as Lithium and Natrium, but I think it's reasonable to assume. Also Potassium is enormously important as a fertilizer in agriculture. It's basically what made modern agriculture possible and allowed the immense population growth of the last century. So that would fit with 'Help Support Half The People On Earth'.

So my guess is this is a Potassium mine?

This is one of the things that is destroying the land and water. It is a lie.  We do not need to add all the fertilizer to the land. Yes it will make plants green and grow but there are much better methods of growing our food that actually helps the land and does not polute our water. They way we grow the majority of crops is destroying the soil.  When you add all this fertilizer it henders and even kills the beneficial microbes that give the plants nutrients. Many nutrients, that our diet is so poor in now. Not to mention that fertilizer is used on monocrops because this is not how nature grows so they have to add things to the soil to get any results. Then you have more pest and weeds come up so they then try and kill these while killing all beneficial organizims and poisons our food. Not to mention all the run off that gets into water ways kills life there all the way to the ocean where it destorys the ecosystem. Causing blooms of sometimes harmful alge and getting into the fish we eat.   And none of it is nessecary!! It is just what corporations want everyone to believe because thats how they make there billions. Most monocrops are also grown using tillage which leaves the soil bare, causing tons of topsoil to get blow away every year and desturbs all the beneficial micro systems causing them to die.  We must change the way we grow our food. It can not continue the way it is, it is just not sustanible.  We need regenerative methods, these are proven to actually increase yleld, provide divirsity, and increase the amount of topsoil and its water absorbtion. This cuts down on the need to irigate and also decreases flooding.  Don't believe propaganda like this.  Learn more about regenerative farming methods. Methods like permaculture, no till farming,  multicrops, organic, composting, to name a few.

To expand on the Saskatchewan mining - You mentioned Sask as if it were just a footnote, when in fact not only did we discover a better way, but we both Have AND Produce more potash in this single province than any COUNTRY on the planet, by far.
1/3 of the worlds potash production is from Canada (almost all of that in Saskatchewan), and nearly half of the worlds potash SUPPLY is underground in Sask.
Those ponds you discussed produce 400,000 US Tons of potash a year. Saskatchewan produces ~22 MILLION US Tons per year, half of which are exported to the US.
The next two largest Producers - Belarus and Russia - make up about 17-18% each, and China is in 4th at 11%. Not counting those 3 countries, the rest of the world COMBINED (USA included) produces less Potash than Saskatchewan. I just find it a bit annoying that this is relegated to a "oh hey these guys figured out a slightly better way to mine it" footnote.

I'm surprised no one said that they were drainage ponds for industrial chemical production. It won't take you more than a few seconds of scanning around ANYWHERE even remotely populated to spot these disgusting looking drainage pools of all different colors. I looked around my state along and found hundreds of them leaking into the river. Naturally, I was appalled at how badly we are polluting our rivers and everything down the line. These pools are filled will all manner of acid/basic heavy metal salts and whatever else. I didn't understand why there were so many pools if they were just throwing it all in the river in the end anyway, and the answer was simple. And it was given to me by a chemist at one of those Oxford Chemist Lectures. "Dilution is the solution to pollution." There are so many of these pools that the crap goes through before hitting the river because they are treating it and letting water evaporate, and in the final pool they discharge just enough of the hopefully fairly neutral PH salts that it doesn't disturb the local fauna.

Great "new" format. Quick correct for the end though: moving from hunter-gathering lifestyles to agriculture did not free up time for prehistoric humans. In fact, the adoption of the new lifestyle made them work longer and harder and caused malnutrition for many generations. Why? Well, hunter-gatherers spend some of their time gathering for a diverse array of food. When they succeed at a hunt, that'll typically feed the group for a while. This lifestyle doesnt feed a dense population groups are small. Modern anthropologists confirm that surviving hunter gatherers today do indeed have shorter work days than farmers did.
The new lifestyle was successful because it produced societies that had inherent advantages over their neigbours: they produced more food, which means they were more numerous and could expand - thus the lifestyle expanded. Famines tended to affect these societies more though, as they couldnt just move to a different area, as quickly all areas of food producers were filled with people, as densely packed as normal non-famine condition farming would allow. Furthermore, farmers had less food diversity in their diet than hunter gatherers, who collected from many availably sources of a large area. Food producers concentrated their efforts and all their time on the limited stuff they could produce.
Yes, that lifestyle also allowed for specialists to arise: with a much larger production, some members of society could specialize and become non-food generating leaders, priests and artisans. It's part of how sedantary food producer societies developped larger collectives, tribes and eventually what we call civilisation.
Only recently has the farming lifestyle become one that the individuals benefit from fully. Nowadays, we reap the rewards for which pretty much 10.000 years of ancestors of food producers lead a shorter, less easy life than they could have as hunter-gatherers (who, evidence shows, were taller and healthier on average than similar food producers)...

Just to clarify for anyone that reads this to the end: in no means should the length of the comment make this a criticism of the show as a whole. It's just an interesting topic I thought of from that 1 relatively small mistake in the end.

cool... I suspected it'd have something to do with evaporation (like how sea salt is made) from the moment I've seen the thumbnail... didn't suspect potash, though... The "blue" I thought it'd be chalcanthite (wrong again, huh)... chalcanthite is in the same "family" as copper sulfate (too bad you didn't say which copper sulfate, cuprous or cupric - if you had, I must've not pay attention, oops, my bad)...

You know, I always search for interesting things near where I live (I walk everywhere) on google earth, but most times it's either something trivial (wow, a pond -.-), or inaccessible, or just not worth the trip (what a waste!)... One exception: Kaolinite surface mines (of which there are plenty around here) - these are pretty amazing up close and personal, not to mention pretty photogenic (all the colors of the layers! It feels like the surface of Mars or something), too (just don't tell on me, because these are off-limits, but that hasn't stop me!)... You see, there's almost always water involved in these (the whole process of "washing" the kaolin clay is pretty interesting, but too long to describe, and to be honest, I don't understand it well quite yet, but it's a "density" thing, some things float, some things sink, you know all that), and the water is (you probably guessed it) blue! Or at least appears to be blue (reflects the sky). The kaolinite from here (not to brag or anything) is like the "purest" in the world, so the norm/standard for the whole world is based on our kaolin/kaolinite (not even the original chinese kaolinite is this pure - you know, kaolin, gaoling... the china/ceramic originates there, chinese pretty much invented it, and you call it "china" in the US, too, right? Right!)... The US just have more of it, is all (ours is still better, lol - quality over quantity), globally it's estimated to be 14 billion metric tons (tonnes - dang the british vs us lingo! lol), so, about 7 billion metric tons is in the US.

Now, with all this shtuff out of the way, I'd like to point you to these unrelated coordinates on google earth: 53.6388533N, 9.4180511E - really bizarre looking "lake" (they mine aluminium oxide, there, that's why the orange/red "rust" color)... just a random find, thought you'd appreciate it ^u^ (I do most of my traveling with finger on the map, anyway, that's the cost of a budget existence... but don't be sorry for me, I'm not really into traveling, except hiking: they said "take a hike!" and so I did, lol)

TL:DR, I know, sorry, but thanks for reading, anyway (much obliged)... and excuse my poor english (I'm self-taught from videogames)

Nice video, tough I would have liked more details into why we need so much potassium to feed people. Most industrialized agriculture nowadays works as a high input/high output system : we put a lot of synthetic minerals in, and a lot of it runs off with water. This is extremely disturbing to the cycles of potassium, phosphorus and nitrogen, it causes pollution (see eutrophisation). It also makes us highly dependent on mining these minerals or synthetising them in the case of nitrogen, which is quite ressource intensive, and in the case of phosphorus, we are simply going to run out of it in the next decades! Note that there are agricultural systems which are low input and low output. It's a bit more expensive than relying on mining and cheap oil, sadly all that matters is lowering costs...

While the educational content is still high, there's a lot here that detracts from the quality in my opinion. The animations are intrusive due to their intentional lack of quality, the music is too loud which sometimes makes it harder to hear Derek, and the tempo is a lot lower (although is isn't necessarily a bad thing if you are aiming for a higher audience).

This is a wonderful video, I love it! However I have to point out there is a serious error at 18.05 - it's stated that "when our ancestors lived as hunter-gatherers we spent all day every day just finding food". This is simply untrue.
Undoubtedly agriculture has enabled large food surpluses that make it feasible for lots of people to have diverse occupations outside of food provisioning. But the idea that agricultural development as a kind of 'liberation' away from a long struggle of hard and brutal hunter-gatherer living is a misconception. Pre-agricultural subsistence strategies did not (and do not) prevent people from partaking in cultural activities - notably including art and music

As a Harvard Neuroscientist, here's a biological perspective on potassium. The wonders and achievements of the 100 billion neurons in each of our brains would not be possible without the exquisitely regulated voltage and concentration gradients of several ions inside and outside of neurons, including potassium. Not only are potassium gradients and their conduction across transmembrane ion channels critical to the dynamics of electrical impulses (action potentials) of neurons, they also establish more complex neural network properties that generate oscillatory rhythmic patterns of activity (known as central pattern generators) to orchestrate our heart beat, respiration, locomotion, and state-dependent gating of different modalities of information processing to and from specific circuits across the brain. 18:06 Hunter-gatherers using ancient tools and techniques today don't spend "all day" just getting food. And there's no reason to believe ancient hunter-gatherers did. Only a few hours a day actually. The rest of the time is spent doing other things, though.

And there's no reason people couldn't have specialized, with some spending all day hunting while others spent all day making arrows, or processing leather, or weaving baskets, pottery, etc. So specialization isn't the power of agriculture.

It's actually just productivity within an area. People don't want to commute more than half an hour each way, which is true today and was true historically based on the distances between and areas of control of ancient villages and the sizes of towns. So a particular area of land has a certain amount of productivity as a wild space where wild animals and fruit grow. But grasslands and pastures can be made far more productive for humans by herding grazing animals. Forest can be made to produce more food if you cut down most of the trees, clear the land, and plant crops. Not only does this technology improve the amount of food one person can produce per year, it improves how much food can be wrested from a particular acre per year.

Agriculture, while not required for specialization to occur, instead all but demands it. When all the land in a given area of control of a village is being worked optimally, there will be population growth, and any extra people will be idle. Typically they will then turn to some other way of supporting themselves, trading their work product for food. Specialization improves productivity of each person. And by demanding specialization, agriculture is an impetus for that.

Settling down instead of being nomadic results in other developments like the concept of property rights, regulation of the day, cultural reinforcement. This encourages improvement of a particular owned region by its inhabitants: dwellings, industry, fortifications, civic structures, roads. Nomads don't care about this stuff. And here we'll see soil fertility improvement through soil amendments like potash and manure. Without agriculture people are just far less likely to settle down and do these things. But these developments improve the resilience of the community and begin to build civilization.

Perhaps as a consequence of agriculture, but perhaps a driver of agriculture, domestication of animals and plants makes them more useful; bearing more fruit, tolerant of drought and pests, extending their growing seasons, making processing easier by reducing chaff, making them tastier or less poisonous, increasing their durability. Long-term storage of grains, pulses, legumes, etc. is foundational to long-term survivability and economy.

So there are many reasons why agriculture was a vital step for hunter-gatherer societies. But they would (and did) carry on just fine until each was inevitably crushed underfoot by an agrarian-to-industrial society.

Hi Derek,
while you clearly still know how to pick very interesting and uncommon topics for a video, I really miss the times when you treated your subject in a more down-to-earth way. Watching this, with all the extra special effects and drone footage cuts, and the mandatory alkali-in-water-explosion ("OOOOH YEAAAH"), I feel like I'm being taken for an ignorant fool with no attention span who needs artificial drama/action to stay focused. If that were the case, I'd be watching something like Mythbusters on the Discovery Channel. While I appreciate the effort you put in making your content, I don't think it's so productive as -at least in my case - it gets in the way of getting your message across. So, pretty please, could you please go back to a more personal and honest type of production? :)

Actually, despite what was stated at approximately 18:20, hunter-gatherers did not spend "all day every day" foraging for food. Peculiarly, the more technologically advanced we got, the more of our day was spent working for our food. Hunter-gatherers spent only 15% of their day seeking food. They had way more leisure time than we did. (Of course, they had no medicine to speak of and no communication — or any other — technology.)

The reason for potassium exploding in water is due to a Coulombic explosion. It’s not because of the hydrogen combusting. That’s a common misconception and it’s worth clearing up.

Basically when electrons leave the potassium metal to react with the water the piece of potassium gets a positive charge and since positive charges repel each other it causes the piece of metal to blow itself apart.
