Very interesting video as always. However, it could have been interesting to open on a less oriented point of view on Potassium.
It indeed is the root of many good things that "free" humanity from the burden of finding food. But our society today is completely altering the benefits, by its over exploitation. Firstly, as of it is produced today, it creates a lot of local pollution, and is sometime a big health problem for local communities. Potassium in the soils are finite, and deforestation (second way of production) is also a major problem for biodiversity. Secondly, it is mostly used in monocultural fields, which are one of the roots of the problem of soils defertilization (which potassium helps to combat). However, other agricultural techniques as permaculture or sylviculture (forestry in english i think), respect way more the natural harmony between plants, with less fertilizers added, and same productivity rate. Potassium has been a launching pad for humanity (as coal or petrol). But let not rely on past successes, that could lead to future disasters.

Love the episode, but I hate that the idea that hunter/gatherers spent every waking moment searching for food. If that was the case then they wouldn’t have had the time to develop agriculture. This may seem like small nitpick, but hunter gatherer societies still exist today and the idea that they’re so busy searching for food leaves them no time for art or music perpetuates the idea that they are more primitive and therefore their culture is less respectable. This idea has real world damaging consequences, like the injustices we are seeing right now against indigenous people in Canada and Brazil.

As a Harvard Neuroscientist, here's a biological perspective on potassium. The wonders and achievements of the 100 billion neurons in each of our brains would not be possible without the exquisitely regulated voltage and concentration gradients of several ions inside and outside of neurons, including potassium. Not only are potassium gradients and their conduction across transmembrane ion channels critical to the dynamics of electrical impulses (action potentials) of neurons, they also establish more complex neural network properties that generate oscillatory rhythmic patterns of activity (known as central pattern generators) to orchestrate our heart beat, respiration, locomotion, and state-dependent gating of different modalities of information processing to and from specific circuits across the brain. 18:14 "We spent all day finding food". This narrative of our ancestors is now somewhat put into question by scholars such as James C Scott. It is not obvious that agriculture in proto-states was an overall positive for those practicing it (due to the high labor cost and lesser resilience it entailed for people who relied before on a variety of food sources). The reasons for certain people to even use agriculture in the first place are actually quite difficult to understand; these reasons might range from change in climate, location and type of nearby bodies, local abundance of food and even political regimes. Agriculture is by no mean a clear-cut progress for any type of society. I believe people such as Derek, who have an ever growing audience and public visibility, should pay a lot of attention to the narrative they push, especially when not doing the research it should entail (as scientific deontology prescribes). The narrative of technological progress as being absolute, disconnected from the reality of societies in which scientific and technological leap actually occurs, is now quite dated and should not (in my humble opinion) be propagated anymore.

Hey there, good video. But...
saying that agriculture relies on potassium is making people believe that there is no other (more sustainable way) of farming. The video is leaving out the needed critical view on fertilising plants with a substance that is normally not there in such an abundance and actually not needed when holistic land management is put into practice. And although it might be good for plants growth in the short run, it is definitely not good in the long run, because it is not beneficial to the health of the soil. For people who are interested in regenerative farming and holistic land management, watch videos of Richard Perkins, Allan Savory and Joel Salatin. There you‘ll find that we are not reliant on any chemical fertiliser.

I'm from Saskatchewan, Canada, and I approve this message.  We also have conventional mines, deep under the surface of the earth, where mining machines (like a big drill crossed with a grinder) break up the potash rocks.  The rocks are sent to the surface to be processed. (Some of the rock is Sodium Chloride, aka common table salt.) It's processed in a wet solution, then dried, then re-compacted into small rocks for distribution to customers. The biggest visible feature of these kinds of mines is the HUGE piles of unwanted salt (reddish in color, from other minerals) on the ground near the mine.

Nobody put fertilizers in forests and yet they have been growing for 350 million years. NPK fertilizers deplete the soils from organic matters and provoke mineralization. The yields go up for a few decades but eventually nothing can grow without artificial inputs. Also if you add synthetic fertilizers, the plants need to absorb a lot of water just to maintain osmotic pressure, so we are essentially buying water for the price of cherry tomatoes. No wonder food has lost its nutritional value and flavors these days... since we confuse Quantity versus Quality. Plants normally take up at least 2 dozens elements from organic soil, if and when they need it. Look up what is permaculture or agroecology if you are curious.

Correction: hunter-gatherer societies (which still exist) typically did not work as much or as hard as early agricultural or even industrial societies. The transition from hunting-gathering or pastoral nomadism to sedentary agricultural civilization is often accompanied by more intense labor (as seen in bone deformations sustained by early farmers as a result of repeated strenuous work) and a decreased quality of life (due to the limited diets brought on by reliance on a select few crops). Agriculture is pretty handy, sure, but it's not such a clear cut improvement.

Who would have thought the most divisive thing to come out of the internet from the past few years would be a Veritasium video.

It is a shame you're getting a lot of negative feedback on this because it was clearly took lot of effort to make. Honestly, the effort paid off because I watched and enjoyed the whole thing. That being said, I don't disagree with the negative feedback - it feels like you were hired as a guest on someone else's show, the animations are a bit off-putting (Humphry Davy is super creepy), and there is something just... missing.

Two of my favorite Veritasium videos are "The Infinite Pattern that Never Repeats" and "This Equation will Change how You See the World". What I like about these is that they, in some way, keep me on the edge of my seat. Just when it seems things can't get any crazier, another layer of depth is uncovered and it just keeps going deeper. It is like looking into the night sky and finding out that what you thought were stars are actually galaxies filled with billions of stars. I feel like I can't comprehend another layer in the topic, but the ride is nowhere near over. It is really thrilling. By comparison, this video feels a bit shallow. Don't get me wrong, it is a really interesting subject, but it feels like there is too much effort put on keeping my attention with flashy things.

This video doesn't deserve some of the more uncharitable comments, but I also don't feel it is your best. I honestly do look forward to seeing more from this series, but I wanted to give some real feedback.

One more small thing: I think the intro "The world is full of mysterious places you can see from above with Google Earth" seems a bit clunky. Maybe "The world is full of mysterious places. You can see them from above with Google Earth" would be punchier. Then again, you're the one with 8 million subscribers so maybe listening to me isn't the best idea.

You should cover the negative impact of fertilizer. They started finding out about these negatives after Aswan Dam was built. With the lack of the annual floods the fields started producing less bountiful crops, after they added fertilizer things went back to normal, for a while. The additional chemicals used to stabilize the fertilizers build up in the soil over time, making them toxic.
This type of poisoning of the fields also happens with heavy pesticide use. Just North of Hope BC along highway 1 they started growing ginseng for the Canadian market. Ginseng has no defence from the insects in Canada and the US so they had to use a lot of pesticides. With ginseng's extremely long growing time ( years per crop ) they also added heavy fertilizer use to get the crops ready for market in a shorter time. 1 acre of ginseng produced in 1 year with these methods kills the soil for 50 years in that acre. This is a prime example that the chemical fertilizers and pest control methods are not good for long term use.

The Hobbesian notion that hunter-gatherers worked constantly just to get enough food to survive has long been disputed, with Marshall Sahlins, Ross Sackett, et al contending that hunter-gatherers actually worked fewer hours per day than people in agricultural societies and as a bonus lived in more egalitarian communities. Agriculture does seem to allow for larger populations, however.

I once did the Potassium demo for my chemistry students -- followed every precaution to a T and was using the tiniest scrap of elemental potassium. Factors converged in just the wrong way, and the wide mouth of my 1L beaker turned into the mouth of a cannon. I had singe marks on the ceiling of my lab until the day I left that school for another one, and I will never forget how time slowed to an absolute crawl as I watched that mess of water, steam and metal rocket upwards into the air -- or how grateful I was that I had made my students stand about 15 feet back, all begoggled (of course. I would never let them in the lab without their goggles).
My students thought it was the best thing they had ever seen, but I think it took about 10 years off the end of my life, lol.

As a Harvard Neuroscientist, the potassium in your body is just as formidable as that contained within mined and manufactured potash salts. The wonders and achievements of the 100 billion neurons in each of our brains would not be possible without the exquisitely regulated voltage and concentration gradients of several ions inside and outside of neurons, including potassium. Not only are potassium gradients and their conduction across transmembrane ion channels critical to the dynamics of electrical impulses (action potentials) of neurons, they also establish more complex neural network properties that generate oscillatory rhythmic patterns of activity (known as central pattern generators) to orchestrate our heart beat, respiration, locomotion, and state-dependent gating of different modalities of information processing to and from specific circuits across the brain. Thanks YouTube! I used to be the plant engineer at this potash plant from 2004-2007. It's still owned by Intrepid Potash Inc. out of Denver. Pretty accurate in all accounts technically. The solution mining method was at first just flooding the original room and pillar underground mine. In 2005 they drilled a set of interconnected horizontal boreholes through the potash bearing strata using the same tech used for horizontal oil and gas drilling. A small point of clarification, but the majority of the evap ponds are actually sodium chloride and the KCL is separated in the plant a few miles east via an amine bubbling process. The remaining sodium saturated water is actually recycled back down the pump shafts. KCL is preferentially soluble in water and this keeps the sodium byproduct from building up. All the feed lines are kept as saturated as possible to minimize corrosion, which as you might imagine can be a big problem.

This is isn't a comment on Veritasium, this is for YouTube.

I really like the idea of providing great content with amazing production, especially when it comes from creators like Veritasium. You did this with Jacksfilms as well, a couple of weeks ago. However, you failed to understand the audience completely both the times. The people that watch these channels don't want to see television style larger-than-life series. If we wanted to see that, we would see telly, not YouTube. The thing I personally like about YouTube is the cut-the-crap attitude that most creators have. Especially from the educational channels. Adding so many bells and whistle is really not necessary.

I'm not sure how much hand YouTube had on the creative process so I probably shouldn't comment too much, but I hope that you see this as constructive criticism. I want high budget documentary style videos from these creators... I really do. However, I would like to see the production be spent on more technical stuff that makes the content more exciting, not the overly commercial audio and visual effects. While the content doesn't suffer from the effects, it does however distract from the video, as the older format serves the content better.

Hi there, awesome video, brilliant material and fascinating content, as usual. Please allow me just a tiny correction: the pools are not visible from space per say (one wouldn't see them from the ISS with a naked eye), they're visible through the magnification of cameras mounted on a satellite in space... It's a bit different. It's like the Great Wall of China, legend has it it's visible from space... well, it isn't: it's just propaganda. The only man-made structures visible from "space" (more accurately from the ISS) with a naked eye are the lights of highly populated areas at night and the Pakistan-India no man's land border in Cashmere... HTH.

TL/DR: Huge fan of the channel, still a subscriber, hate the format of this Youtube Original, worried that it could lead to a change in the channel in the future

Huge fan of the channel. But geez this youtube original show is super hard to watch. Most of the things that I really like about a regular Veritasium videos--namely how they respect the intelligence and attention span of the viewer--aren't present. This new show is way overproduced, way too loud, and gimicky in such a pandering, intelligence insulting way. Which is a shame, because I think the content of this episode is really interesting. I realize you might not have a ton of creative control on this project and I also know that you'd be a fool to pass up on a youtube original (totally get that) but please don't feel like you have to reinvent the wheel to grow your channel in the future. The things that drew me to your channel (and probably a ton of people like me) wasn't the production value or the scale, but rather how you tackle interesting topics in a straightforward, yet laymen friendly manner. I don't need loud Hans Zimmer rip off scores and tacky animated cut outs of US presidents to learn something new and cool. This feels like a bad History channel show. I had to turn it off after 5 minutes.

Major fact mistake: hunter gatherers (of South America, Eastern Africa, Australia etc) spent on average two to three hours per day 'gathering' food. They had (and where they still exist - still have) an immediately available abundance of food for more easily accessed than anything in the so called developed world. It is a complete myth that hunter gatherers were/are time poor and that free time is what gave rise to the arts and other superfluous pursuits.

True - the Neolithic revolution (i.e. the invention of farming) was the cradle from which civilisation as we know it grew. However, to laud our modern culture as something to be thankful for is very old fashioned and borders on offensive in this day and age. The Neolithic concentration of resources immediately gave rise to inequality and thus, war, poverty, famine, exploitation, environment devastation and resource overshoot. If any of these plagues sound familiar it's because they are the very same ones that threaten our very existence today.

Interesting but man the editing style almost made me stop watching. A big reason I’ve liked videos from Veritasium, Smarter Every Day, et al is because they let the content speak for itself, without all the flashy over-the-top bells and whistles you see on the Discovery channel or whatever. That’s just mindless fluff that tries to grab the viewer’s attention but adds nothing to the video, and ends up being an annoying distraction that makes the whole thing worse. Not only that, this particular style feels almost dated, like something from 2007.

If this was an attempt to appeal to younger kids I think it’s misguided, because kids can so easily tell when educational videos are pandering to them. Flashy editing won’t pull kids in, it’ll just make them feel like they’re in school. What will pull them in is interesting content that’s presented straightforwardly with no BS. If you don’t believe me just look at TikTok - some of the most popular videos on there are just regular people showing how they do their jobs.

17:46 Come to think of it. What is the expiry date of this planet? Where is the point when every resource of this planet is exploited and utilized all by the ever-increasing population of this planet?

Fertilizer is a double edge sword known to plant scientists as "plant crack" because we have removed one of the most important links in the ecology fungi. Fungi are natures fertilizer they digest rocks extracting minerals and then trade those minerals with plants in exchange for sugar. Plants are unable to access mineral nutrients they can only access nutrients dissolved in water. As a consequence of skipping the fungi commercial fertilizers must be water soluble and that means that as a result almost all the commercial fertilizers used run off rather than get absorbed where they flow down stream driving excessive growth until oxygen levels in the water are depleted resulting in eutrophication. Very cool video. The whole Moab Valley is a result of a salt plume (aka: Paradox Formation) uplifting the area, being dissolved out, and the void roof collapsing down, over a period of time. There are fault lines mapped on the parameter of the valley, resulting in a non-seismogenic earthquake threat because of this dissolution process. The recent geologic hazard maps outline this hazard for the area.  Many of the surrounding valleys were formed this way.

As a Harvard Neuroscientist, the potassium in your body is just as formidable as that contained within mined and manufactured potash salts. The wonders and achievements of the 100 billion neurons in each of our brains would not be possible without the exquisitely regulated voltage and concentration gradients of several ions inside and outside of neurons, including potassium. Not only are potassium gradients and their conduction across transmembrane ion channels critical to the dynamics of electrical impulses (action potentials) of neurons, they also establish more complex neural network properties that generate oscillatory rhythmic patterns of activity (known as central pattern generators) to orchestrate our heart beat, respiration, locomotion, and state-dependent gating of different modalities of information processing to and from specific circuits across the brain. Great video, but one information in particular is wrong. In 18:07 Derek says that hunter-gatherers spent most of their time finding food. Actually they worked less than the average person in industrialized societies, at least according to the best knowledge available in anthropology. In his book "Work", James Suzman talks about the relationship that hunter-gatherers had with work. His main object of study, the Ju/'Hoansi, worked an average of 17h/week looking for food in the Kalahari Desert plus 20h/week in domestic work. And this is mostly true for all living hunter-gatherers societies. Most people in the "developed"/developing world work 40-44h (not even counting domestic work), that is waay more than the time we used to work back then. Probably most of people in hunter-gatherer societies had more time to engage in cultural activities such as creating art and music, and spending time with their family and friends. Today very few people have the time and resources to fulfill those human needs. Anyway, learned lots of facts about Potassium! Thanks!!

The answer is:
They use water to flush potash (potassium compounds) out of the underground mine into these 23 ponds.
The ponds are blue because copper sulfate is added to prevent algae growth, and blue water absorbs sunlight better and hence evaporates faster.
After several months, all the water evaporates and white potash crystals are left and collected to be sold.

18:09. Wrong. Hunter gatherers spent most day every day sleeping and relaxing, having fun. On an average day they "worked" 4h to supply what they needed. One deer/antilope/any other medium sized animal could sustain whole group for days, and since they could not preserve food, there was no point hunting more until last prey was eaten. Unfortunatly, nature just could not make enough crops so our ancestor could make lots of beer. Hence agriculture was born, with land property, wealth for selected few and 18h working day every day for all the rest.

while the brine pump method seems a lot less environmentally damaging than mine shafts... i still can't help but wonder what are the inevitable impacts on the environment.

my first guess is that using water in a desert is both expensive and somewhat wasteful, tho utah clearly isn't suffering any life-threatening drought.

second guess is that pumping water into the earth at an industrial scale might have undesirable effects, like forcing some of the brine to seep into the water table - altho this might not apply here if the water pressure isn't super high (like in fracking) and perhaps the salt pockets aren't near enough to the water table to be of any concern; or perhaps any potash brine seepage is simply not harmful enough to be a concern.

As a Harvard Neuroscientist, the potassium in your body is just as formidable as that contained within mined and manufactured potash salts. The wonders and achievements of the 100 billion neurons in each of our brains would not be possible without the exquisitely regulated voltage and concentration gradients of several ions inside and outside of neurons, including potassium. Not only are potassium gradients and their conduction across transmembrane ion channels critical to the dynamics of electrical impulses (action potentials) of neurons, they also establish more complex neural network properties that generate oscillatory rhythmic patterns of activity (known as central pattern generators) to orchestrate our heart beat, respiration, locomotion, and state-dependent gating of different modalities of information processing to and from specific circuits across the brain. There's a whole debate about why people started farming anyway, especially considering that early farming was a much less reliable food source (plus takes longer) than hunting/gathering. Farming does generate more food per capita once you advance far enough in history to get a couple of key innovations working and this is needed for large civilizations, but this comes at the expense of good nutrition, long hard days of work, and a usually-oppressive ruling class. If you measure quality of life strictly based on free time, the original hunter-gatherers were the highest living people to exist.

We talked at great length about all this in a university archaeology class so I don't remember the sources right now, but a google search titled something like "the original affluent society" should pull the relevant books and research papers fairly easily.

Also, can't say I love the editing style; it's a bit hard to follow and the music is distracting, but I love your work enough that it's alright.

My HS chemistry teacher, Mr. Magenheimer, was a great teacher. He clearly loved science and his enthusiasm was infectious.
He also often had singed eyebrows.
One day, he decided to show us the potassium in water experiment. He had us all stand on the other side of the classroom. Then he took a ONE INCH CUBE, SERIOUSLY, THE THING WAS ENORMOUS, of potassium and chucked into the lab sink, which was full of water. The poor clock on the wall above never worked again, but we all had a newly deep respect for both science and BIG BADDA BOOMS! 😂😍💜💜 Wherever you are now, Mr. Magenheimer, I hope you know that you are a true inspiration. You ensured our safety, THEN showed us how cool chemistry could be.
